name: Antenna
description: A machine ponders its loneliness. It scans the radio spectrum for an answer to its question.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 Processor: 2 GHz dual core Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: Hardware Accelerated Graphics DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 300 MB available space Sound Card: Any but ideally Creative Sound Blaster or equivalent Additional Notes: Requires Sound on to play
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 10 Processor: 2 GHz quad core + Memory: 8 GB RAM Graphics: Hardware Accelerated Graphics DirectX: Version 10 Storage: 300 MB available space Sound Card: Any but ideally Creative Sound Blaster or equivalent + Additional Notes: Requires Sound on to play

reviews.review_text: A completely dark game... confusing. Clean your ears, it will help you   a lot.   Also try to use a headphone. The game is unique in it's own way, you need to have time and patience to play it. But hey, it's a free game, try it. :)
Love the overall feeling of this game. Very great job but sadly very short.

If this is the short film before the full feature, then I would look forward to that. I hadn't really thought about sound puzzles until playing this and I think it's worth exploring further. Turns out I'm not very good at them, but I enjoyed it nonetheless. I rarely stumble on something interesting in the free to play section, but I'm glad I gave this a chance. My first thought after seeing the logo, I expected it to be some wifi troubleshooting software like inSSIDer, but I'm glad it's a game instead. Anyway, it's good to experiment and I hope the positive feedback encourages you to work on something bigger in the vein of Limbo or Deadlight. If you have to go for a Microsoft timed-exclusive deal, then I understand, but know that we'll still be waiting for you here, when you finally come to your senses.

I have the feeling that this game if made by and for audiophiles. If you can easily distinguish between two tunes/sounds and like to play around with it... this is your game. Personally, I've had no fun at all because I had to look everything up (because I didn't even understand what I was supposed to do) and then had to do it on my own anyway because everyone seems to have a unique solution. And I had no fun finding the solution because I just couldn't distinguish between all the sounds that I was hearing.  Apart from that... I also have my problems with the 'story'. I don't have a problem with games (or movies for that matter) not telling us every detail of the world and let us do some thinking of our own... but here we don't have anything at all. Not the slightes hint on what is going on. Are we the last robot on earth who miserably tries to fix antennas? Are we just fixing antennas? Why are there antennas?  On the plus side: - it's free - easy/quick perfect game - graphics are ok

No. Don't bother with it. It's pointless and the controls are badly disigned. You are given no descriptions of what you are suppose to do, the environment is bland and boring, the sounds are genric and get very, very repetitive and irritating quickly.   The loading screens (Signal) last way too long, the opening does nothing to draw you in and it's unskippable (it probably isn't loading anything behind it because there's no substance, nothing to load).   You'll find that when you are prompted to press a key, it can be anywhere on your keyboard or your mouse. Your 'charcter' walks rediculously slowly for no reason at all, except to make this longer than it needs to be. Which makes no sense since it adds nothing to the experience (what little there is).   As you can see, I've spent just under 30min playing this 'game', and I have no desire to force myself to play any more of it. After sitting at a gong puzzle (match the sounds) and hearing the same sound come from all four squares for 10minutes, adjusting the sliders minutely over and over hoping to find the 'right sound', I said screw it.   It's not worth your time.
Very slow puzzle game. And your objective is to search for the missing signal.

Steam doesn't like the 5 Star system when it comes to reviews? Well, 4/5 stars will sand this on the recommended side of the spectrum. Very simple game, unique tasks to complete in comparison to any other generic puzzle game. The mechanics are different from what I expected, using a mousewheel for a handful of tasks. Quite interesting for a game. I love the simple 'graphics'. 2D, monochromatic, and the sound design is simple, yet somewhat soothing to my ears.  Only (not even a complaint) issue is the length. I played for I think 17 minutes, Steam had told me. And that is including the time it took to boot up and get trhough the start menu (1-2 minutes).  BUT, if a short game is what you people are looking for, this is otherwise a fivestar game. I would certainly recommend it!  NOTE ON HIDDEN ACCIEVEMENT: I have no idea what it is. I only played through it once, but I feel that if I play through it enough times, I'll figure it out. I love surprises!

It's a simple, short, albeit enjoyable existence, and it's free!   For half an hour of your time you can't go wrong.   There's plenty of Steam guides to help out if you (somehow) get stuck on a puzzle.   (hint: play with your transmit buttons, then hit both of them when you find the right frequency)

Short, simple, and sweet. It reminds me a lot of Limbo, beacuse of the artstyle and detailed scenery. There is some story behind this, but either i'm too dull to get it, or I didn't look hard enough... There are four achievements just for doing small puzzles and such, but there is a fifth, hidden achievement...  The fact you could go faster by holding shift did unsettle me though...why would you need it? I honestly did expect something to chase me at anytime during the experience.   There is more to this than meets the eye, I can feel it... From what i've gathered from the broadcasts though, it does seem that this game takes place in Russia perhaps (some of the voices did seem to be talking in what sounded like Russian, but this is coming from a guy whose best Spanish translates to something close to 'The cat runs up a ladder'). Maybe after a war? I did hear some of the NATO alphabet at one point.  I liked it for it's simplicity and beauty. However, it's simple enough to beat in around seven minutes, so if that isn't enough for you, then don't play it. Duh. Now I sail my ship (S.S. Obvious) to other waters.

Geriatric alien cockroach walking simulator.  Expect to be transported to a shadowy alien world for about 25 minutes, a place dominated by mechanical radio communication attennae. The store description is apt: a short experience, an atmospheric expression. Recommended because it's free and has effective sound design, but the expression they're going for is let down by its dour and workmanlike implementation.

If you come to this game expecting something life changing you're going to be disapointed. Don't expect the next Skyrim, Don't expect the next Fallout4, just clear your mind of expectations. The 'I'm new to this game and don't know how to do stuff' feel makes you really relate to the piece of machinery you play as.  It feels like you just got sentience, but barely. When you first walk in the game it gives you a feeling of acomplishment, and that's really cool. You have no idea why this little guy is doing what he does, you barely even know what he is doing. All you know is that it's what you're made to do.  The controls seem kinda awkward at times making you play twister on your keybored, but it added to the 'Old machinery' feel I think, the old outdated machanics got you annoyed, not the game itself.  This game will never let me hear spring peepers the same way again. So I guess you could say it is life changing. Just subtly.

I would love to see more of this game in the future. My 0.3 hours was well spent.

Antenna  wasn't what I expected it to turn out to be, based on the discerption of on the store page. I was expecting more game length from it, but for a free-to-play, casual, puzzle title, I can hardly complain. With it being in a slightly unusual in format, as well as being a puzzle game, it can cause a great deal of frustration to players that are missing a key hint as to what to do next.   One thing I need to point out is that the puzzles are sound based, hence the theme of  Antenna ! You need to listen carefully to get through the puzzles.   It is really short once you know how to puzzle it out, like with most fixed puzzle games, but with such games it is not for the impatient when first playing through it. I would recommend checking the game’s Community Hub for a hint or technical help if stuck. I needed to, since the interface had a slight glitch with the “?” button, and the implied hint of what to do kind of went over my head on the first puzzle. Heh, woops.  Anyway, if you are looking for a short break from other games, I would recommend checking this one out. You can likely beat it in one or two sittings, but the visual, and especially audio, details in it are what really make it interesting. Any armature radio operator would like find the details in the radio chatter almost a puzzle in of itself, since there are some encoded messages in it as well.

What an awesome little game. ^_^ Great atmosphere and it has a particular attraction for me as a SW Radio enthusiast. My only complaint is that it's way too short and sweet. I had completed the whole game in less than 30 mins. This is one game I'd love to see an extended version of with far more levels and achievements..

Strange little game. There are two interesting, sound-based puzzles in it. They were rather easy but worth it for the novelty value. The art style is rather nice - very reminiscent of Limbo.  I'm not entirely sure what its point is. It took 20 minutes to play through, and I've no idea what the fifth achievement is. Did I miss a puzzle? Or was there something I missed on the frequency dial?  This strikes me as more of a piece of performance art than a game. There's no reason not to take 25 minutes out of your day to play it though, since it's free.
Well overall I liked the game , it was a little short . The enviroment was good and the visual and audio ingame was also very good . So good job and keep it up .

This game is incredibly calming and relaxing. Immediately prior to playing this game, I was playing a horror game that left me very apprehensive, so at first I was cautious with this game due to its dark colors and lonely sounds, but as I played, I noticed myself calming.  In addition to this, as I am quite fond of puzzles, and audio puzzles are not very common, this game was also rather stimulating with its few, albeit interesting, puzzles.  All in all, this game is great for relaxing, destressing, and simply taking a moment to breathe.
Interesting short puzzle game. You gonna need good hearing skills for the puzzles.
A wonderful refined simple game, with the design similar to my all-time favourite 'The Fall', containing four puzzles, a touching story, and complete solutide.
